values.description:
* Add save models logic to logging such that replay does not depend on downloading models

* Add default behaviour to record with models as disabled, save model file only when --record_with_model added to the argument

* Use GetDefaultTestPath() for gazebo7

* Fix tests and not breaking ABI

* Mark new Start function as the one that is expected to be deprecated and don't give default value to _recordWithModel

* style tweaks

* fix abs path, model insertion, saving files, add test

* exists

* only print many bullet console warnings one time

* Creating branch to investigate ODE Revolute Joint initialization issue

* Creating fixes and tests for issue 2430

* Resolve a few code check complaints

* Fixes based on reviewer feedback

* changelog

* add expectations on return value of SetPosition, add test case for super-large angles with logic for bullet

* add ssao plugin and material

* add test

* cleanup, doc

* update test

* changelog

* check null mat

* move mat del to private destructor

* add ogre's licenseheader

* set gbuffer visibility mask

* fix build

* fix camera control inside model bbox

* add test world

* change to drill in test

* changelog

* use ign math equal

* fix ray triangle intersection check in Scene::FirstContact function

* changelog

* update comment

* add return doxy

* camera.cc remove redundant Disconnect call

* changelog

* Close branch bullet_quiet8

* Close branch mouse_bbox_7

* Style tweaks -> pull request #2916

* style tweaks and a couple of extra checks

* Close branch ambient_occlusion_7_louise

* ignore object that has material using alpha rejection

* Close branch FixSetPositionForODEandBullet

* Close branch ray_triangle_7

* Close branch ambient_occlusion_7

* save files return

* Remove recordpath in testing

* Close branch logging_with_models_gazebo7

I was able to reproduce the [build error](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64/239/console) after upgrading boost on my laptop.

The changes should fix the build

values.description:
Fixes GpuRaySensor with more than one vertical ray (see issue [#946](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/946/gpu-ray-sensor-vertical-ranges)).

The configuration is identical to the CPU RaySensor.
values.title: Fix GpuRaySensor vertical rays

summary.raw:
Fixes GpuRaySensor with more than one vertical ray (see issue [#946](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/946/gpu-ray-sensor-vertical-ranges)).

The configuration is identical to the CPU RaySensor.
summary.html:
Fixes GpuRaySensor with more than one vertical ray (see issue #946).

The configuration is identical to the CPU RaySensor.

values.description:
This adds support for Heightmaps with DART when using Bullet or ODE collision detectors in DART. It requires changes in [DART PR #1069](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/pull/1069) which has recently been merged and included in DART release 6.6.

This relates to issue #909, but it will only fix #909 as soon as DART supports Heightmaps in the default collision detector \(FCL\).

I also found an issue with the heightmaps using the Bullet collision detector when I added the new _TerrainCollision_ test. I have opened a separate issue #2506 for this. Therefore, in this PR the _TerrainCollision_ test is skipped for bullet. When the issue is solved, the test skipping can be undone again.

DART 6.6 is required. For running the complete test, the following dart packages must be installed:

    apt-get install libdart6-dev
    apt-get install libdart6-collision-bullet-dev

and optionally also the use of ODE in dart can be tested, though this is technically not topic of this PR:

    apt-get install libdart6-collision-ode-dev

If the bullet and/or ode extensions are not installed, the tests are skipped.

I have also added some world files which can be used to visually test how heightmaps work.

The following uses a slanted terrain and drops 5 boxes on it. They are expected to roll down the slope.

     gazebo <src-dir>/test/worlds/heightmap_test_with_boxes.world

This world has a valley and drops a sphere on it, which is expected to roll down the valley and stay there.

     gazebo <src-dir>/test/worlds/heightmap_test_with_boxes.world

Use the `-e` parameter to change physics as usual.

When using bullet, you'll see it won't work due to issue #2506.

For DART, it will only work when using Bullet or ODE as DART collision detector. It won't work with the default DART collision detector yet \(which uses FCL\). So to test with DART, we still will need to specify the collision detector to use in the `<physics>` tag. There valley-sphere world has been modified twice to include this tag, once for Bullet and once for ODE:

    gazebo <src-dir>/test/worlds/heightmap_test_with_sphere_dart_bullet.world
    gazebo <src-dir>/test/worlds/heightmap_test_with_sphere_dart_ode.world
values.title: Dart heightmap with bullet and ODE

summary.html:
This adds support for Heightmaps with DART when using Bullet or ODE collision detectors in DART. It requires changes in DART PR #1069 which has recently been merged and included in DART release 6.6.

This relates to issue #909, but it will only fix #909 as soon as DART supports Heightmaps in the default collision detector (FCL).

I also found an issue with the heightmaps using the Bullet collision detector when I added the new TerrainCollision test. I have opened a separate issue #2506 for this. Therefore, in this PR the TerrainCollision test is skipped for bullet. When the issue is solved, the test skipping can be undone again.

DART 6.6 is required. For running the complete test, the following dart packages must be installed:

apt-get install libdart6-dev
apt-get install libdart6-collision-bullet-dev

and optionally also the use of ODE in dart can be tested, though this is technically not topic of this PR:

apt-get install libdart6-collision-ode-dev

If the bullet and/or ode extensions are not installed, the tests are skipped.

I have also added some world files which can be used to visually test how heightmaps work.

The following uses a slanted terrain and drops 5 boxes on it. They are expected to roll down the slope.

 gazebo <src-dir>/test/worlds/heightmap_test_with_boxes.world

This world has a valley and drops a sphere on it, which is expected to roll down the valley and stay there.

 gazebo <src-dir>/test/worlds/heightmap_test_with_boxes.world

Use the -e parameter to change physics as usual.

When using bullet, you'll see it won't work due to issue #2506.

For DART, it will only work when using Bullet or ODE as DART collision detector. It won't work with the default DART collision detector yet (which uses FCL). So to test with DART, we still will need to specify the collision detector to use in the <physics> tag. There valley-sphere world has been modified twice to include this tag, once for Bullet and once for ODE:

gazebo <src-dir>/test/worlds/heightmap_test_with_sphere_dart_bullet.world
gazebo <src-dir>/test/worlds/heightmap_test_with_sphere_dart_ode.world

values.description:
BulletHingeJoint [doesn't fully support joint limits outside of (-pi,pi)](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/42). If you try to set a joint limit outside that range, it won't actually set a limit that will be enforced by the dynamics, but it will report limits that are truncated to the range (-pi,pi).

For example, the double pendulum model has joint limits listed as (-1.30, 1.30), even though they are set to be (-1e16, 1e16).

![bullet_joint_limit.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/412529355-bullet_joint_limit.png)

With this pull request, a helper function is added so that the btHingeConstraint::setLimit function isn't called for invalid joint limits. The joint limits will now be reported as (1, -1), which is bullet's way of saying that no joint limits are active (upper_limit < lower_limit).

I noticed this issue while trying to debug test failures in pull request #2953.
values.title: Improve BulletHingeJoint support for large joint limits

summary.raw:
BulletHingeJoint [doesn't fully support joint limits outside of (-pi,pi)](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/42). If you try to set a joint limit outside that range, it won't actually set a limit that will be enforced by the dynamics, but it will report limits that are truncated to the range (-pi,pi).

For example, the double pendulum model has joint limits listed as (-1.30, 1.30), even though they are set to be (-1e16, 1e16).

![bullet_joint_limit.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/412529355-bullet_joint_limit.png)

With this pull request, a helper function is added so that the btHingeConstraint::setLimit function isn't called for invalid joint limits. The joint limits will now be reported as (1, -1), which is bullet's way of saying that no joint limits are active (upper_limit < lower_limit).

I noticed this issue while trying to debug test failures in pull request #2953.
summary.html:
BulletHingeJoint doesn't fully support joint limits outside of (-pi,pi). If you try to set a joint limit outside that range, it won't actually set a limit that will be enforced by the dynamics, but it will report limits that are truncated to the range (-pi,pi).

For example, the double pendulum model has joint limits listed as (-1.30, 1.30), even though they are set to be (-1e16, 1e16).

With this pull request, a helper function is added so that the btHingeConstraint::setLimit function isn't called for invalid joint limits. The joint limits will now be reported as (1, -1), which is bullet's way of saying that no joint limits are active (upper_limit < lower_limit).

I noticed this issue while trying to debug test failures in pull request #2953.

values.description: BulletHingeJoint doesn't correctly report joint limits outside of [-pi,pi] ([upstream issue](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/42)), so this returns our cached value of the joint limits instead of calling the bullet API. The is an alternative to pull request #2958, which didn't work in all cases.
values.title: Fix getting joint limits for BulletHingeJoint

summary.raw: BulletHingeJoint doesn't correctly report joint limits outside of [-pi,pi] ([upstream issue](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/42)), so this returns our cached value of the joint limits instead of calling the bullet API. The is an alternative to pull request #2958, which didn't work in all cases.
summary.html: BulletHingeJoint doesn't correctly report joint limits outside of [-pi,pi] (upstream issue), so this returns our cached value of the joint limits instead of calling the bullet API. The is an alternative to pull request #2958, which didn't work in all cases.

values.description:
A generic flash light plugin: **FlashLightPlugin**. It accesses <light> elements under <link> and makes them to flash and dim based on the given parameters \(duration and interval\). It has TurnOn/Off functions so a plugin inherited from this class can activate flash lights without touching ~/light/modify topic, like turning on/off a bike headlight.

A demo world file: **flash\_light\_plugin\_demo.world**. A model has two links \(cylinder and box\) and each link has two lights attached on it. Based on the parameters, the lights on the cylinder keep blinking while the ones on the box are either turned off or staying constant.

Testing code:** INTEGRATION\_flash\_light\_plugin**. It is to verify that the plugin publishes correct messages to control the lights. It listens to ~/light/modify topic and measures the actual duration/interval time and the last update time of each light. It passes if the error is within 0.01 sec.
values.title: Flash light plugin

summary.raw:
A generic flash light plugin: **FlashLightPlugin**. It accesses <light> elements under <link> and makes them to flash and dim based on the given parameters \(duration and interval\). It has TurnOn/Off functions so a plugin inherited from this class can activate flash lights without touching ~/light/modify topic, like turning on/off a bike headlight.

A demo world file: **flash\_light\_plugin\_demo.world**. A model has two links \(cylinder and box\) and each link has two lights attached on it. Based on the parameters, the lights on the cylinder keep blinking while the ones on the box are either turned off or staying constant.

Testing code:** INTEGRATION\_flash\_light\_plugin**. It is to verify that the plugin publishes correct messages to control the lights. It listens to ~/light/modify topic and measures the actual duration/interval time and the last update time of each light. It passes if the error is within 0.01 sec.
summary.html:
A generic flash light plugin: FlashLightPlugin. It accesses <light> elements under <link> and makes them to flash and dim based on the given parameters (duration and interval). It has TurnOn/Off functions so a plugin inherited from this class can activate flash lights without touching ~/light/modify topic, like turning on/off a bike headlight.

A demo world file: flash_light_plugin_demo.world. A model has two links (cylinder and box) and each link has two lights attached on it. Based on the parameters, the lights on the cylinder keep blinking while the ones on the box are either turned off or staying constant.

Testing code: INTEGRATION_flash_light_plugin. It is to verify that the plugin publishes correct messages to control the lights. It listens to ~/light/modify topic and measures the actual duration/interval time and the last update time of each light. It passes if the error is within 0.01 sec.

values.description:
~~This builds on top of pull request #2949 and needs [this](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/73/fix-returned-download-path-for-tip/diff) Fuel-tools PR.~~

---

Adds support for full Fuel URLs in SDF's `<uri>` tag.

Most models on Fuel use the `model://` scheme, but you can try [this coffee maker](https://ignitionfuel.org/chapulina/models/Coffee%20Maker), which has the following SDF:

~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <model name="coffee_maker">
    <static>true</static>
    <link name="link">
      <visual name="visual">
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
            <uri>https://api.ignitionfuel.org/1.0/chapulina/models/Coffee Maker/tip/files/meshes/coffee_maker.obj</uri>
            <scale>0.01 0.01 0.01</scale>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
      </visual>
    </link>
  </model>
</sdf>
~~~




![coffeefuel.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1388587355-coffeefuel.gif)
values.title: Fuel: Support models with full Fuel URLs in <uri>

summary.raw:
~~This builds on top of pull request #2949 and needs [this](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/73/fix-returned-download-path-for-tip/diff) Fuel-tools PR.~~

---

Adds support for full Fuel URLs in SDF's `<uri>` tag.

Most models on Fuel use the `model://` scheme, but you can try [this coffee maker](https://ignitionfuel.org/chapulina/models/Coffee%20Maker), which has the following SDF:

~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <model name="coffee_maker">
    <static>true</static>
    <link name="link">
      <visual name="visual">
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
            <uri>https://api.ignitionfuel.org/1.0/chapulina/models/Coffee Maker/tip/files/meshes/coffee_maker.obj</uri>
            <scale>0.01 0.01 0.01</scale>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
      </visual>
    </link>
  </model>
</sdf>
~~~




![coffeefuel.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1388587355-coffeefuel.gif)
summary.html:
This builds on top of pull request #2949 and needs this Fuel-tools PR.

Adds support for full Fuel URLs in SDF's <uri> tag.

Most models on Fuel use the model:// scheme, but you can try this coffee maker, which has the following SDF:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <model name="coffee_maker">
    <static>true</static>
    <link name="link">
      <visual name="visual">
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
            <uri>https://api.ignitionfuel.org/1.0/chapulina/models/Coffee Maker/tip/files/meshes/coffee_maker.obj</uri>
            <scale>0.01 0.01 0.01</scale>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
      </visual>
    </link>
  </model>
</sdf>

values.description:
Fixes the failing gazebo\_ros\_pkgs barrel distortion test: [https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo\_ros\_pkgs/issues/681](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/681)

It appears that we weren’t recomputing the distortion scale when the “crop” setting was changed, so if crop was set to false, the changes weren’t ever propagated.
values.title: Fix gazebo_ros_pkgs barrel distortion test

summary.raw:
Fixes the failing gazebo\_ros\_pkgs barrel distortion test: [https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo\_ros\_pkgs/issues/681](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/681)

It appears that we weren’t recomputing the distortion scale when the “crop” setting was changed, so if crop was set to false, the changes weren’t ever propagated.
summary.html:
Fixes the failing gazebo_ros_pkgs barrel distortion test: https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/681

It appears that we weren’t recomputing the distortion scale when the “crop” setting was changed, so if crop was set to false, the changes weren’t ever propagated.

values.description:
I've added a few missing changelog entries between this release and the 9.0.0 tag:

* #!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/gazebo9%0Dgazebo9_9.0.0#pull-requests

There were a few pull requests missing and one duplicate entry from the gazebo7 and gazebo8 changelogs, so I fixed them with direct commits to those branches and merged forward to here:

* 7:  9c1cb5f
* 8:  8d8d3aa

values.description:
A test for the ODE slip parameter was added in pull request #2717. This behavior of this parameter currently depends on the number of contact points acting on a given collision. I've added a box to the friction_sphere test world to illustrate this in 6706fe1 along with expectations that the box should behave the same as the `lowball` models, since they each have one collision shape. Those expectations fail in that commit, but they are fixed by 73f6813, which adjusts the `ODEPhysics::Collide` function to account for the number of contact points when setting the slip parameters. This fixes the test.

I will create an animation of the test world to show this as well.
values.title: Improve ODE slip parameter behavior with multiple contact points

Those expectations fail in that commit, but they are fixed by 73f6813, which adjusts the `ODEPhysics::Collide` function to account for the number of contact points when setting the slip parameters. This fixes the test.

I will create an animation of the test world to show this as well.

values.description:
This patch allows the HeightmapLODPlugin to set the skirt length for LOD tiles. The default skirt length is 10m which creates a lot of large polygons beneath the terrain which unnecessarily increases polygon fill burden and makes it difficult to see the DEM LOD behavior when viewing in wireframe.

Reducing skirt length to 0.2m improved framerate by about 50% in my high resolution DEM test case.
values.title: LOD skirt length

summary.raw:
This patch allows the HeightmapLODPlugin to set the skirt length for LOD tiles. The default skirt length is 10m which creates a lot of large polygons beneath the terrain which unnecessarily increases polygon fill burden and makes it difficult to see the DEM LOD behavior when viewing in wireframe.

Reducing skirt length to 0.2m improved framerate by about 50% in my high resolution DEM test case.
summary.html:
This patch allows the HeightmapLODPlugin to set the skirt length for LOD tiles. The default skirt length is 10m which creates a lot of large polygons beneath the terrain which unnecessarily increases polygon fill burden and makes it difficult to see the DEM LOD behavior when viewing in wireframe.

Reducing skirt length to 0.2m improved framerate by about 50% in my high resolution DEM test case.

values.description:
This targets pull request #2950 and adds an additional test with the `trisphere_cycle` model added in [gazebo_models PR 330](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/330/tricycle-with-spherical-wheels/diff). The test involves two of these vehicles driving against an inclined gravity vector (to simulate uphill driving) with different levels of slip compliance. The model with less slip compliance (bottom) generates more linear velocity that the model with more slip compliance (top).

![wheel_slip_trisphere_cycle_shorter.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3682756510-wheel_slip_trisphere_cycle_shorter.gif)

To simplify the implementation of this test, I added a `JointController::SetForce` API, which can set a persistent force to be applied at a joint. This can currently be done by publishing to a `joint_cmd` topic or using the JointControlWidget, but there wasn't a c++ API until now.

I also added some `const` specifiers to the inputs of some JointController functions, since I don't think this affects API/ABI. I will revert those changes if they are a problem.
values.title: WheelSlipPlugin: add test with trisphere_cycle

summary.raw:
This targets pull request #2950 and adds an additional test with the `trisphere_cycle` model added in [gazebo_models PR 330](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/330/tricycle-with-spherical-wheels/diff). The test involves two of these vehicles driving against an inclined gravity vector (to simulate uphill driving) with different levels of slip compliance. The model with less slip compliance (bottom) generates more linear velocity that the model with more slip compliance (top).

![wheel_slip_trisphere_cycle_shorter.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3682756510-wheel_slip_trisphere_cycle_shorter.gif)

To simplify the implementation of this test, I added a `JointController::SetForce` API, which can set a persistent force to be applied at a joint. This can currently be done by publishing to a `joint_cmd` topic or using the JointControlWidget, but there wasn't a c++ API until now.

I also added some `const` specifiers to the inputs of some JointController functions, since I don't think this affects API/ABI. I will revert those changes if they are a problem.
summary.html:
This targets pull request #2950 and adds an additional test with the trisphere_cycle model added in gazebo_models PR 330. The test involves two of these vehicles driving against an inclined gravity vector (to simulate uphill driving) with different levels of slip compliance. The model with less slip compliance (bottom) generates more linear velocity that the model with more slip compliance (top).

To simplify the implementation of this test, I added a JointController::SetForce API, which can set a persistent force to be applied at a joint. This can currently be done by publishing to a joint_cmd topic or using the JointControlWidget, but there wasn't a c++ API until now.

I also added some const specifiers to the inputs of some JointController functions, since I don't think this affects API/ABI. I will revert those changes if they are a problem.

values.description: This adds a hierarchical profiler, which is useful to establish where run time is being used.  It also corrects some issues with IntrospectionManager using too much time to do needless copies.
values.title: Add GZ_PROFILE and IntrospectionManager speedup

summary.raw: This adds a hierarchical profiler, which is useful to establish where run time is being used.  It also corrects some issues with IntrospectionManager using too much time to do needless copies.
summary.html: This adds a hierarchical profiler, which is useful to establish where run time is being used. It also corrects some issues with IntrospectionManager using too much time to do needless copies.

values.reason: This will be updated to use the profiler from ign-common3.

values.description: In working on [vmrc](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/vmrc/src), gzserver crashed when loading a height map from a [world file](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/vmrc/src/default/robotx_gazebo/models/sandisland/model.sdf) which appears to be correctly setup.  In HeightMap::InitBlendMaps, blendMaps is initialized assuming \_terrain has blendHeight.size\(\) \+ 1 elements. If this is not true, the loop will go out of bounds. This adds a check for that condition similar to other safety checks above it.
values.title: Check terrain layer count in height map

summary.raw: In working on [vmrc](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/vmrc/src), gzserver crashed when loading a height map from a [world file](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/vmrc/src/default/robotx_gazebo/models/sandisland/model.sdf) which appears to be correctly setup.  In HeightMap::InitBlendMaps, blendMaps is initialized assuming \_terrain has blendHeight.size\(\) \+ 1 elements. If this is not true, the loop will go out of bounds. This adds a check for that condition similar to other safety checks above it.
summary.html: In working on vmrc, gzserver crashed when loading a height map from a world file which appears to be correctly setup. In HeightMap::InitBlendMaps, blendMaps is initialized assuming _terrain has blendHeight.size() + 1 elements. If this is not true, the loop will go out of bounds. This adds a check for that condition similar to other safety checks above it.

values.description:
A patch for the problem when a visual message is sent just after the simulator starts.

If a message to modify an existing visual object is sent to ~/visual topic at the very beginning, a duplicate visual object is created and the original one is never updated.

Thanks to @iche033 , the problem was found and fixed as follows.

This update should be applied to gazebo7 and later versions.
values.title: Patch for visual message process

summary.raw:
A patch for the problem when a visual message is sent just after the simulator starts.

If a message to modify an existing visual object is sent to ~/visual topic at the very beginning, a duplicate visual object is created and the original one is never updated.

Thanks to @iche033 , the problem was found and fixed as follows.

This update should be applied to gazebo7 and later versions.
summary.html:
A patch for the problem when a visual message is sent just after the simulator starts.

If a message to modify an existing visual object is sent to ~/visual topic at the very beginning, a duplicate visual object is created and the original one is never updated.

Thanks to @iche033 , the problem was found and fixed as follows.

This update should be applied to gazebo7 and later versions.

values.description:
Replace protobuf scoped_ptr with std::unique_ptr, since scoped_ptr's were removed in protobuf 3.6.

Fixes #2483.

The fix for 8 and 9 is more complicated because of ignition-msgs, but this works for gazebo7.
values.title: Fix build on homebrew with protobuf 3.6

summary.raw:
Replace protobuf scoped_ptr with std::unique_ptr, since scoped_ptr's were removed in protobuf 3.6.

Fixes #2483.

The fix for 8 and 9 is more complicated because of ignition-msgs, but this works for gazebo7.
summary.html:
Replace protobuf scoped_ptr with std::unique_ptr, since scoped_ptr's were removed in protobuf 3.6.

Fixes #2483.

The fix for 8 and 9 is more complicated because of ignition-msgs, but this works for gazebo7.

summary.raw: checking CI

values.title: Play logs as close to real time as possible

values.description:
The fix for protobuf 3.6 (which fixes the homebrew build) was merged to gazebo7 in pull request #2984. In pull request #2985, it was merged forward to gazebo8, along with support for vertical rays in GPU ray sensor from pull request #2955. There are lots of [conflicts](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/gazebo8?dest=gazebo9#chg-gazebo/rendering/GpuLaser.hh) with the GPU ray sensor between pull request #2955 and pull request #2637 from @sloretz that added the `GpuLaserDataIterator`, so I have cherry-picked 3190bab instead of a full branch merge in order to fix the homebrew build more quickly.

I will merge if CI is happy.
values.title: Cherry-pick protobuf 3.6 fix -> 9

summary.raw:
The fix for protobuf 3.6 (which fixes the homebrew build) was merged to gazebo7 in pull request #2984. In pull request #2985, it was merged forward to gazebo8, along with support for vertical rays in GPU ray sensor from pull request #2955. There are lots of [conflicts](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/gazebo8?dest=gazebo9#chg-gazebo/rendering/GpuLaser.hh) with the GPU ray sensor between pull request #2955 and pull request #2637 from @sloretz that added the `GpuLaserDataIterator`, so I have cherry-picked 3190bab instead of a full branch merge in order to fix the homebrew build more quickly.

I will merge if CI is happy.
summary.html:
The fix for protobuf 3.6 (which fixes the homebrew build) was merged to gazebo7 in pull request #2984. In pull request #2985, it was merged forward to gazebo8, along with support for vertical rays in GPU ray sensor from pull request #2955. There are lots of conflicts with the GPU ray sensor between pull request #2955 and pull request #2637 from @sloretz that added the GpuLaserDataIterator, so I have cherry-picked 3190bab instead of a full branch merge in order to fix the homebrew build more quickly.

I will merge if CI is happy.

values.title: Add PR 2967 to changelog and bump version to 8.6.0

values.description:
Fixes issue #2479. I can backport to release branches later.

That was a tough one to track down. The issue was being caused by the `EditorMaterialSwitcher`, which is the one responsible for making all models that are not being edited white while one model is being edited. That ignores GUI visuals, which collision visuals are, so setting this flag appropriately fixes the issue.

This fixes two situations, enter the link inspector's collision tab and:

1. Change the collision geometry - the new collision shouldn't be white
1. Delete all collisions, then add one collision - the new collision shouldn't be white

FYI @mrunzzz
values.title: [Model Editor] Fix material for new collisions

summary.raw:
Fixes issue #2479. I can backport to release branches later.

That was a tough one to track down. The issue was being caused by the `EditorMaterialSwitcher`, which is the one responsible for making all models that are not being edited white while one model is being edited. That ignores GUI visuals, which collision visuals are, so setting this flag appropriately fixes the issue.

This fixes two situations, enter the link inspector's collision tab and:

1. Change the collision geometry - the new collision shouldn't be white
1. Delete all collisions, then add one collision - the new collision shouldn't be white

FYI @mrunzzz
summary.html:
Fixes issue #2479. I can backport to release branches later.

That was a tough one to track down. The issue was being caused by the EditorMaterialSwitcher, which is the one responsible for making all models that are not being edited white while one model is being edited. That ignores GUI visuals, which collision visuals are, so setting this flag appropriately fixes the issue.

This fixes two situations, enter the link inspector's collision tab and:

  1. Change the collision geometry - the new collision shouldn't be white
  2. Delete all collisions, then add one collision - the new collision shouldn't be white

FYI @mrunzzz

values.description:
In my overnight testing, I've noticed several seg-faults when de-referencing a null `rendering::Light` pointer in the `CameraSensor.Light` test. There are two issues here:

* we are using `EXPECT_TRUE` instead of `ASSERT_TRUE` when checking pointers.
* there is a typo and the `sensor` pointer is checked instead of `sun`.

This just helps the test fail more cleanly, but I've noticed that it's pretty flaky. I've never seen it pass 10 times in a row. It typically fails with the `sun` pointer being null. I've tried adding a wait loop, but it doesn't seem to help. I'm not sure how to improve it. Do you have any ideas @iche033?
values.title: CameraSensor.Light test: change some EXPECT to ASSERT

summary.raw:
In my overnight testing, I've noticed several seg-faults when de-referencing a null `rendering::Light` pointer in the `CameraSensor.Light` test. There are two issues here:

* we are using `EXPECT_TRUE` instead of `ASSERT_TRUE` when checking pointers.
* there is a typo and the `sensor` pointer is checked instead of `sun`.

This just helps the test fail more cleanly, but I've noticed that it's pretty flaky. I've never seen it pass 10 times in a row. It typically fails with the `sun` pointer being null. I've tried adding a wait loop, but it doesn't seem to help. I'm not sure how to improve it. Do you have any ideas @iche033?
summary.html:
In my overnight testing, I've noticed several seg-faults when de-referencing a null rendering::Light pointer in the CameraSensor.Light test. There are two issues here:

  • we are using EXPECT_TRUE instead of ASSERT_TRUE when checking pointers.
  • there is a typo and the sensor pointer is checked instead of sun.

This just helps the test fail more cleanly, but I've noticed that it's pretty flaky. I've never seen it pass 10 times in a row. It typically fails with the sun pointer being null. I've tried adding a wait loop, but it doesn't seem to help. I'm not sure how to improve it. Do you have any ideas @iche033?

* Call event::Events::stop\(\) when GUI is stopped
* Call event::Events::sigInt\(\) when GUI receives sigInt

* Call event::Events::stop\(\) when server is stopped
* Call event::Events::stop\(\) when GUI is stopped
* Call event::Events::sigInt\(\) when GUI receives sigInt

Reference issue #2495

  • Call event::Events::stop() when server is stopped
  • Call event::Events::stop() when GUI is stopped
  • Call event::Events::sigInt() when GUI receives sigInt

values.description:
# Overview

`LedPlugin` to blink a visual object, synchronizing the `FlashLightPlugin`.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oLe6g9a/images/1622346296-led.gif)
‌

And an updated version of the `FlashLightPlugin` so it can switch colors of the light.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oLe6g9a/images/4260459456-color_blocks.gif)
‌

It accepts `<block>` element as a plugin parameter to define a light pattern. The example below defines that the light element \(`link1/light_source` \) casts red light for 0.6 sec, followed by 0.2 sec of green light and 0.5 sec of dim, and it repeats this pattern.

    <plugin ... >
      <light>
        <id>link1/light_source</id>
        <block>
          <duration>0.6</duration>
          <interval>0</interval>
          <color>1 0 0</color>
        </block>
        <block>
          <duration>0.2</duration>
          <interval>0.5</interval>
          <color>0 1 0</color>
        </block>
      </light>
    </plugin>

# Implementation of LedPlugin

Here are details about the structure and implementation of `LedPlugin`.

`LedPlugin` inherits the `FlashLightPlugin`. The following diagram shows the internal components.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oLe6g9a/images/1335009940-LED.png)
`FlashLightPlugin` has a list of `FlashLightSetting` objects, each of which takes care of an individual light object. They call `Flash` and `Dim` functions which send a message to `~/light/modify` topic at a specified timing, i.e., duration and interval time.

`LedPlugin` extends this structure and has a list of `LedSetting` objects which are descendants of `FlashLightSetting`. They override `Flash` and `Dim` functions to send a message to `~/visual` topic so a corresponding visual object can be updated synchronously.

## Initialization of extended setting objects

The data inside `LedPlugin` and `FlashLightPlugin` are implemented in PIMPL, and they are invisible to each other. This causes a problem when a `FlashLightSetting` is extended. It needs to be instantiated in `LedPlugin` while the objects are stored inside `FlashLightPlugin`. Also an object needs to be initialized by data in each level.

To have `LedPlugin` hold an extension class of `FlashLightSetting`, it overrides two functions: `CreateSetting` and `InitSettingBySpecificData`.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oLe6g9a/images/1601523865-initLED.png)
The `Load` function of the plugin reads SDF data and creates a setting object for each light. \(1. Call and 2. Instantiate in the diagram\) It first calls `CreateSetting` function. This function is overridden and instantiates the corresponding class. That is,

```c++
std::shared_ptr<FlashLightSetting> LedPlugin::CreateSetting(
  const sdf::ElementPtr &_sdf,
  const physics::ModelPtr &_model,
  const common::Time &_currentTime)
{
  return std::make_shared<LedSetting>(_sdf, _model, _currentTime);
}
```

After that, it calls `InitSettingBySpecificData` function, which initializes variables in `LedSetting`. It also calls the parent's function so those in `FlashLightSetting` are also initialized. \(4. Call 5. Initialize 6. Initialize in the diagram\)

P.S. I am sorry for this complicated structure. I appreciate any comments and suggestions!
values.title: LED plugin and color blocks to FlashLight Plugin

summary.raw:
# Overview

`LedPlugin` to blink a visual object, synchronizing the `FlashLightPlugin`.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oLe6g9a/images/1622346296-led.gif)
‌

And an updated version of the `FlashLightPlugin` so it can switch colors of the light.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oLe6g9a/images/4260459456-color_blocks.gif)
‌

It accepts `<block>` element as a plugin parameter to define a light pattern. The example below defines that the light element \(`link1/light_source` \) casts red light for 0.6 sec, followed by 0.2 sec of green light and 0.5 sec of dim, and it repeats this pattern.

    <plugin ... >
      <light>
        <id>link1/light_source</id>
        <block>
          <duration>0.6</duration>
          <interval>0</interval>
          <color>1 0 0</color>
        </block>
        <block>
          <duration>0.2</duration>
          <interval>0.5</interval>
          <color>0 1 0</color>
        </block>
      </light>
    </plugin>

Here are details about the structure and implementation of `LedPlugin`.

`LedPlugin` extends this structure and has a list of `LedSetting` objects which are descendants of `FlashLightSetting`. They override `Flash` and `Dim` functions to send a message to `~/visual` topic so a corresponding visual object can be updated synchronously.

It needs to be instantiated in `LedPlugin` while the objects are stored inside `FlashLightPlugin`. Also an object needs to be initialized by data in each level.

summary.html:
Overview

LedPlugin to blink a visual object, synchronizing the FlashLightPlugin.

‌

And an updated version of the FlashLightPlugin so it can switch colors of the light.

‌

It accepts <block> element as a plugin parameter to define a light pattern. The example below defines that the light element (link1/light_source ) casts red light for 0.6 sec, followed by 0.2 sec of green light and 0.5 sec of dim, and it repeats this pattern.

<plugin ... >
  <light>
    <id>link1/light_source</id>
    <block>
      <duration>0.6</duration>
      <interval>0</interval>
      <color>1 0 0</color>
    </block>
    <block>
      <duration>0.2</duration>
      <interval>0.5</interval>
      <color>0 1 0</color>
    </block>
  </light>
</plugin>

Implementation of LedPlugin

Here are details about the structure and implementation of LedPlugin.

LedPlugin inherits the FlashLightPlugin. The following diagram shows the internal components.

FlashLightPlugin has a list of FlashLightSetting objects, each of which takes care of an individual light object. They call Flash and Dim functions which send a message to ~/light/modify topic at a specified timing, i.e., duration and interval time.

LedPlugin extends this structure and has a list of LedSetting objects which are descendants of FlashLightSetting. They override Flash and Dim functions to send a message to ~/visual topic so a corresponding visual object can be updated synchronously.

Initialization of extended setting objects

The data inside LedPlugin and FlashLightPlugin are implemented in PIMPL, and they are invisible to each other. This causes a problem when a FlashLightSetting is extended. It needs to be instantiated in LedPlugin while the objects are stored inside FlashLightPlugin. Also an object needs to be initialized by data in each level.

To have LedPlugin hold an extension class of FlashLightSetting, it overrides two functions: CreateSetting and InitSettingBySpecificData.

The Load function of the plugin reads SDF data and creates a setting object for each light. (1. Call and 2. Instantiate in the diagram) It first calls CreateSetting function. This function is overridden and instantiates the corresponding class. That is,

std::shared_ptr<FlashLightSetting> LedPlugin::CreateSetting(
  const sdf::ElementPtr &_sdf,

  const common::Time &_currentTime)

}

After that, it calls InitSettingBySpecificData function, which initializes variables in LedSetting. It also calls the parent's function so those in FlashLightSetting are also initialized. (4. Call 5. Initialize 6. Initialize in the diagram)

values.description:
I'm not sure yet what caused it, but as reported on issue #2487, something broke manipulation in the model editor between 9.0.0 and 9.1.1. [Here](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/gazebo9_9.1.1%0Dgazebo9_9.0.0#chg-gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc)'s the diff between them if anyone wants to take a look. 

The reason for the failures is that model editor links also return true for the condition *If it is not a model and its parent is either a direct child or grandchild of the world, this is a light*. I'm not sure what changed or why it used to work, but the chart on pull request #1613 helps understand the visual tree a bit.

I've tested that the following manipulations work with this pull request:

* Lights in simulation
* Models in simulation
* Nested models in simulation (i.e. root model is manipulated)
* Links in the model editor
* Nested models in the model editor (i.e. top level nested model is manipulated)
values.title: [issue #2487] Fix manipulating links in the model editor

summary.raw:
I'm not sure yet what caused it, but as reported on issue #2487, something broke manipulation in the model editor between 9.0.0 and 9.1.1. [Here](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/gazebo9_9.1.1%0Dgazebo9_9.0.0#chg-gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc)'s the diff between them if anyone wants to take a look. 

The reason for the failures is that model editor links also return true for the condition *If it is not a model and its parent is either a direct child or grandchild of the world, this is a light*. I'm not sure what changed or why it used to work, but the chart on pull request #1613 helps understand the visual tree a bit.

I've tested that the following manipulations work with this pull request:

* Lights in simulation
* Models in simulation
* Nested models in simulation (i.e. root model is manipulated)
* Links in the model editor
* Nested models in the model editor (i.e. top level nested model is manipulated)
summary.html:
I'm not sure yet what caused it, but as reported on issue #2487, something broke manipulation in the model editor between 9.0.0 and 9.1.1. Here's the diff between them if anyone wants to take a look.

The reason for the failures is that model editor links also return true for the condition If it is not a model and its parent is either a direct child or grandchild of the world, this is a light. I'm not sure what changed or why it used to work, but the chart on pull request #1613 helps understand the visual tree a bit.

I've tested that the following manipulations work with this pull request:

  • Lights in simulation
  • Models in simulation
  • Nested models in simulation (i.e. root model is manipulated)
  • Links in the model editor
  • Nested models in the model editor (i.e. top level nested model is manipulated)

* Avoid unnecessary copies
